what: Functions and code snippets for the R&E team at the CHC
title: Functions and code snippets for the R&E team at the CHC
text: chcRne package developed organize functions, useful code snippets, information relevant Research Evaluation team Center Healthy Communities.

title: Functions and code snippets for the R&E team at the CHC
Functions and code snippets for the R&E team at the CHC
text: Functions section used data management. using yesno_to_binary change q14_1 - q14_10 yes/1/0. Now column mark apply question 1/0, using pnta.unanswered..miss() set columns select apply question NA “Prefer answer” option selected.
code: library(chcRne) library(dplyr)  data <- bns2_pkg_data %>% select(q13, q14_1:q14_10)  df_converted <- yesno_to_binary(data, "q14_") # View the converted dataframe side-by-side old <- bns2_pkg_data |> dplyr::select(q14_1, q14_4) new <- df_converted |> dplyr::select(q14_1, q14_4) cbind(old, new) %>% head(10) ##    q14_1 q14_4 q14_1 q14_4 ## 1     No    No     0     0 ## 2    Yes   Yes     1     1 ## 3   <NA>  <NA>    NA    NA ## 4    Yes    No     1     0 ## 5     No   Yes     0     1 ## 6    Yes    No     1     0 ## 7    Yes   Yes     1     1 ## 8    Yes   Yes     1     1 ## 9     No   Yes     0     1 ## 10   Yes   Yes     1     1 df_unanswered_to_miss <- pnta.unanswered.to.miss(data = df_converted,                                   prefix = "q14_",                                   pnta = bns2_pkg_data$q14_30) new <- df_unanswered_to_miss %>%  select(q14_3:q14_5, q14_30) new$q14_30 <- df_converted$q14_30 new %>% head(10) ## # A tibble: 10 × 4 ##    q14_3 q14_4 q14_5 q14_30 ##    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> ##  1    NA    NA    NA      1 ##  2     0     1     0      0 ##  3    NA    NA    NA      0 ##  4     0     0     0      0 ##  5     0     1     0      0 ##  6     0     0     0     NA ##  7     0     1     0      0 ##  8     0     1     0      0 ##  9    NA    NA    NA      1 ## 10    NA    NA    NA      1

title: Functions and code snippets for the R&E team at the CHC
text: Functions section creation tables R&E team frequently uses. nperc_tbl_MATA() Creates table showing n counts percentages option mark apply question. question_table creates table counts percentages single categorical variable.
code: cols <- c("q14_3", "q14_4", "q14_5") rnames <- c("I like cooking", "I am a broke college student", "I live with chefs")  # Create table that reports n count and percent for a mark all that apply question mark_all_that_apply_tbl <- nperc_tbl_MATA(df = df_unanswered_to_miss,                vars = cols,                value = "1",                row.names = rnames,                punc = ".") mark_all_that_apply_tbl ##                                           Yes (%) ## I am a broke college student. (n = 37) 15 (40.5%) ## I live with chefs. (n = 40)             4 (10.0%) ## I like cooking. (n = 40)                 3 (7.5%) question_tbl <- question_table(data = bns2_pkg_data,                 x = 'q13',                 cnames = c("Level of Education", "Yes %"),                 kbl_styling = TRUE) question_tbl

title: Functions and code snippets for the R&E team at the CHC
text: Functions section return statistics often used explanations figures. Many functions often used inline code. print_n_reporting() count_and_percent() Returns string includes total count percentage categories input variable. get_perct()

Creates frequency table — nperc_tbl_MATA
text: function creates table showing n counts percentages option mark apply question.

title: Creates frequency table — nperc_tbl_MATA
Creates frequency table — nperc_tbl_MATA
text: df data frame used create table. vars character vector variable names include table (vars binary). value value rows `vars` (one value across variables). row.names name row table. equivalent option select apply question punc punctuation end row names.

title: Creates frequency table — nperc_tbl_MATA
text: frequency table

title: Creates frequency table — nperc_tbl_MATA
code: # Save the variable names to questions and the names of the questions to rnames cols <- c("q14_1", "q14_3", "q14_4")  nperc_tbl_MATA(df = bns2_pkg_data,                vars = cols,                value = "Yes",                row.names = c("I am a broke college student","No good restaurants", "I like cooking"),                punc = ".") #>                                           Yes (%) #> I like cooking. (n = 44)               21 (47.7%) #> I am a broke college student. (n = 47) 16 (34.0%) #> No good restaurants. (n = 47)            3 (6.4%)

PNTA to NA — pnta.unanswered.to.miss
text: data data frame interest. prefix prefix used identify relevant columns. pnta variable contains "Prefer answer" option.

title: PNTA to NA — pnta.unanswered.to.miss
text: modified data frame NA assigned cells specified columns rows PNTA responses.

title: PNTA to NA — pnta.unanswered.to.miss
code: updated_data <- pnta.unanswered.to.miss(data = bns2_pkg_data,                                   prefix = "q14_2",                                   pnta = bns2_pkg_data$q14_30) #> Error in `[<-`(`*tmp*`, n.answer == 0, these.cols, value = NA): Can't assign rows with `n.answer == 0`. #> ✖ Subscript `n.answer == 0` can't contain missing values. #> ✖ It has missing values at locations 3, 17, 28, 30, and 34. updated_data |> dplyr::select(q14_20:q14_26, q14_30) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'updated_data' not found

what: Table of Counts Percentages for Single Question — question_table
title: Table of Counts Percentages for Single Question — question_table
text: function takes dataset specified column representing single categorical binary variable (e.g., level education) creates table response percentages. table can optionally styled using `kableExtra` better visualization.

title: Table of Counts Percentages for Single Question — question_table
Table of Counts Percentages for Single Question — question_table
text: data data frame containing dataset analyzed. x name column `data` containing question cnames character vector length 2 specifying column names resulting table. first element category name second percentages. kbl_styling logical value indicating whether style table `kableExtra`. Defaults TRUE. TRUE, table returned `kableExtra` styling applied.

title: Table of Counts Percentages for Single Question — question_table
text: table percentages specified question. `kbl_styling` TRUE,   table styled `kableExtra` suitable markdown rendering.   Otherwise, plain data frame returned.

title: Table of Counts Percentages for Single Question — question_table
code:
question_table(data = bns2_pkg_data, x = 'q13', cnames = c("Level of Education", "Yes %"), kbl_styling = TRUE) #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #>
Level of Education Yes %
Less than high school 28 (57.1%)
High school diploma or GED 9 (18.4%)
Some college 8 (16.3%)
Associate's degree 2 (4.1%)
Bachelor's degree 1 (2.0%)
Other/Unknown 1 (2.0%)

what: Convert Yes/No Variables to Binary — yesno_to_binary
title: Convert Yes/No Variables to Binary — yesno_to_binary
text: function takes dataframe prefix identify specific columns names. converts "Yes"/"" responses columns binary numeric values, "" 0 "Yes" 1.

title: Convert Yes/No Variables to Binary — yesno_to_binary
Convert Yes/No Variables to Binary — yesno_to_binary
text: data dataframe containing variables converted. prefix character string used select columns name. Columns whose names start prefix "Yes"/"" values converted 0/1.

title: Convert Yes/No Variables to Binary — yesno_to_binary
text: original dataframe specified Yes/variables converted binary numeric values.

title: Convert Yes/No Variables to Binary — yesno_to_binary
code: # Convert "Yes"/"No" responses in columns starting with "q14" to 0/1 df_converted <- yesno_to_binary(bns2_pkg_data, "q14_")  # View the converted dataframe side-by-side old <- bns2_pkg_data |> dplyr::select(q14_1, q14_4) new <- df_converted |> dplyr::select(q14_1, q14_4) cbind(old, new) #>    q14_1 q14_4 q14_1 q14_4 #> 1     No    No     0     0 #> 2    Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 3   <NA>  <NA>    NA    NA #> 4    Yes    No     1     0 #> 5     No   Yes     0     1 #> 6    Yes    No     1     0 #> 7    Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 8    Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 9     No   Yes     0     1 #> 10   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 11   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 12    No    No     0     0 #> 13    No   Yes     0     1 #> 14   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 15    No   Yes     0     1 #> 16    No  <NA>     0    NA #> 17   Yes    No     1     0 #> 18   Yes    No     1     0 #> 19   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 20    No   Yes     0     1 #> 21    No  <NA>     0    NA #> 22    No    No     0     0 #> 23   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 24    No    No     0     0 #> 25   Yes    No     1     0 #> 26    No    No     0     0 #> 27    No    No     0     0 #> 28  <NA>  <NA>    NA    NA #> 29    No   Yes     0     1 #> 30    No    No     0     0 #> 31    No    No     0     0 #> 32    No    No     0     0 #> 33    No    No     0     0 #> 34  <NA>  <NA>    NA    NA #> 35    No  <NA>     0    NA #> 36    No    No     0     0 #> 37    No    No     0     0 #> 38    No   Yes     0     1 #> 39    No    No     0     0 #> 40    No   Yes     0     1 #> 41    No    No     0     0 #> 42    No   Yes     0     1 #> 43    No   Yes     0     1 #> 44   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 45   Yes   Yes     1     1 #> 46    No   Yes     0     1 #> 47    No    No     0     0 #> 48    No    No     0     0 #> 49    No    No     0     0 #> 50   Yes    No     1     0
